Feature

Neuroblastoma

Wilms Tumor (Nephroblastoma)

Age of Onset

Typically diagnosed in children < 5 years (median age 22 months).

Peak incidence between 2 and 5 years (95% by age 10).

Location

Arises in the adrenal glands (abdominal, retroperitoneal).

Arises in the kidneys (unilateral or bilateral).

Bilateral in about 10% of cases.

Bilateral in 5-10% of cases.

Small round blue cells, rosettes, neuroblasts.

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient is diagnosed with malignant pheochromocytoma after presenting with persistent hypertension and elevated plasma metanephrines. Imaging reveals metastasis to various sites. Which of the following is not a common site for metastasis?
questions.explanation:
Malignant Pheochromocytoma

Tumors that have undergone metastasis to Lymph-node (or) Distant site (Biochemically same as Pheochromocytoma)

Survival Rate

5-year survival ranges from 20% to 45%.

Criteria of Malignancy

Malignancy is defined by the development of metastases

Common Sites of Metastasis

Axial skeleton, lymph nodes, liver, lung, and kidney. (Option A,C,D)

Diagnosis

  • MIBG & Gallium Dotate is Best for Diagnosis
  • Biopsy & FNAC are avoided in Malignant Pheochromocytoma
  • Confirmed by the presence of metastases in locations where neuroectodermal tissues are not normally found.
  • This is the primary criterion distinguishing malignant pheochromocytomas from benign ones, as histopathologic features alone are not reliable in predicting malignancy.

Histopathologic Criteria

No histopathologic criteria can accurately predict the clinical course of malignancy.

Primary Treatment

Surgical resection, even if not curative, can offer significant palliative benefits by managing mass effects and reducing catecholamine excess.

Response to Radiotherapy/Chemotherapy

Minimal response to radiotherapy and chemotherapy.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman in her 24th week of pregnancy presents with severe headaches, palpitations, and paroxysmal hypertension. Laboratory investigations reveal elevated plasma metanephrines, and imaging confirms the presence of a pheochromocytoma. Which of the following is the most appropriate management strategy for this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Use phenoxybenzamine and plan laparoscopic adrenalectomy in the second trimester.

options.label: B
options.text: Wait until the third trimester, use Labetalol to control BP, and perform a C-section followed by adrenalectomy.

options.label: C
options.text: Use calcium channel blockers and plan for surgical resection postpartum.

questions.correct_answer: A. Use phenoxybenzamine and plan laparoscopic adrenalectomy in the second trimester.
questions.explanation:
Biochemical Diagnosis

Identify pheochromocytoma using biochemical tests and imaging for localization.

Preoperative Preparation
  • Start with an α-adrenoceptor blocker like phenoxybenzamine.
  • Adjust the dose to 100-160 mg/day to achieve postural hypotension.
  • Add β-blockers if necessary after α-blockade to manage tachycardia.
  • Other regimens include α-blockade with doxazosin or prazosin, with and without β-blockers, calcium channel blockers alone, and using catecholamine synthesis blocker metyrosine in cardiac failure.

Surgery
  • Laparoscopic Adrenalectomy: Preferred for PCC unless tumor >10 cm or malignant signs are present.
  • Open Surgery: Recommended for large tumors or those along the sympathetic chain.

Postoperative Care
  • Monitor for hypovolemia and hypoglycemia for 24 hrs post-surgery.
  • Conduct annual biochemical tests for recurrence.

Malignant Pheochromocytoma
  • Perform surgical excision, possibly with en bloc resection for invasive tumors.
  • Consider adjuvant therapies like radiolabeled MIBG and octreotide.

Pheochromocytoma in Pregnancy
  • First/Second Trimester: Implement α-blockade, then proceed with laparoscopic adrenalectomy.
  • Third Trimester: Plan for an elective C-section followed by adrenalectomy 6 weeks later.

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient presents with elevated serum calcium levels and a neck mass. After further evaluation, the diagnosis of parathyroid carcinoma is confirmed. The patient is scheduled for surgery. What is the standard surgical treatment for this case to minimize the risk of local recurrence?
questions.explanation:
PARATHYROID CARCINOMA

Clinical Features
  • Parathyroid carcinoma is responsible for 1% of cases of primary hyperparathyroidism.
  • Age of onset: 44 to 54 years
  • Serum Calcium: >14 mg/dL (Mean 14.6 to 15.9 mg/dL)
  • Serum PTH: 5 to 10 fold higher than normal levels.
  • Neck Mass: Present in 34-52% of patients.
  • Evidence of bone disease, renal disease, or pancreatitis may be present.

Diagnosis
  • Suspicion: Elevated serum calcium, high PTH, neck mass, or parathyroid crisis.
  • Pathologic Features: Trabecular pattern, mitotic figures, thick fibrous bands, capsular/vessel invasion.
  • Definitive Diagnosis: Local invasion or metastases.
  • Immunohistochemistry: Parafibromin loss (100% specificity), Ki-67, galectin-3, PGP 9.5.
  • Molecular Markers: Loss of parafibromin, upregulation of PGP 9.5.

Management of Parathyroid Carcinoma

En-Bloc Resection

(Option B)

Includes removal of adjacent invaded tissues; performed in 12.5% of cases

Resectable Parathyroid Carcinoma (Local or regional recurrence of parathyroid carcinoma)
  • En-bloc resection is standard for initial and recurrent disease, involving the removal of the tumor along with any invaded structures.
  • Lymph Node Dissection: Performed only if lymph node involvement is confirmed. (Option C)
    CDC73/HRPT2 Variant Carriers: Bilateral exploration or selective resection of abnormal glands.
  • Total parathyroidectomy is not favored. (Option D)
  • Metastasis: Spreads locally, invading adjacent structures in the neck such as the thyroid gland and strap muscles.
  • Surgical resection of metastasis for palliation of hypercalcemia
  • Post-op Serum Calcium Monitoring: Essential for managing "hungry bone syndrome".

Medical Therapy for Unresectable Parathyroid Carcinoma (When parathyroid carcinoma is not resectable due to widespread dissemination)
  • Managed with hypercalcemia control and palliative care.
  • Bisphosphonates: Intravenous zoledronic acid or pamidronate. Calcimimetics: Cinacalcet is used if bisphosphonates are ineffective.

It works on the calcium-sensing receptor (CASR) of the parathyroid gland and controls the parathyroid hormone.

  • Denosumab: For hypercalcemia, refractory to bisphosphonates and cinacalcet.

Biotherapy

Emerging therapies include parafibromin inhibitors, telomerase inhibitors, and immune therapies.

Two days postoperatively, she presents with numbness and tingling around her mouth and in her fingers. She also complains of muscle cramps and mild weakness. Laboratory tests reveal decreased serum calcium levels. What is the most likely cause of her symptoms following the surgery?

options.label: B
options.text: Hypocalcemia due to damage to the parathyroid glands

questions.correct_answer: B. Hypocalcemia due to damage to the parathyroid glands
questions.explanation:
HYPOPARATHYROIDISM

Common Causes:

Thyroid Surgery

Most frequent cause.

is damage to the parathyroid glands or their blood supply. (Option B)

Risk Factors:

  • Bilateral neck exploration,
  • Extensive central neck dissection,
  • Revision surgery,
  • Thyroidectomy for Graves' disease,
  • Pediatric patients.

Autoimmune Disorders

Autoimmune polyendocrine syndrome type 1 (APS-1).

Genetic Conditions

DiGeorge syndrome, autosomal dominant hypocalcemia.

Radiation Therapy

Radiation to the neck area can damage parathyroid glands.

Medications

Lithium, and some chemotherapeutic agents (Pembrolizumab).

Prevention:

  • Surgical Precautions:
  • Careful dissection and preservation of parathyroid glands.
  • Examine surgical specimens for removed parathyroid tissue.
  • Autotransplant confirmed parathyroid tissue into the sternocleidomastoid muscle.
  • Calcium and Vit D Supplementation:
    • Administer calcium (with/without calcitriol) proactively for total thyroidectomy patients.
    • Measure intraoperative PTH or intact PTH levels four hours postoperatively to guide supplementation.

Management:

  • Temporary Hypoparathyroidism: Resolves within 6 months.
  • Permanent Hypoparathyroidism: Requires ongoing calcium and/or Vit D replacement.

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman with a history of tertiary hyperparathyroidism undergoes total parathyroidectomy. Three days later, she presents with carpopedal spasms and numbness around her mouth. Her serum calcium level is 6.9 mg/dL. What is the most likely diagnosis?
A 57-year-old patient with chronic renal failure is found to have elevated parathyroid hormone levels, but his serum calcium level is in the normal range. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Secondary hyperparathyroidism (Option C)

Definition

Physiologic response of parathyroid glands to hypocalcemia

Causes
  • Chronic renal failure:
    • ￬ phosphate excretion
    • ￪serum phosphate binds to serum calcium & ￬free serum calcium levels.
    • ￬1-hydroxylase activity in the kidney ➜ ￬ 1,25 (OH)2 vitamin D formation ➜ ￬ intestinal absorption of calcium.
    • This results in increased secretion of parathyroid hormone.
  • Vitamin D deficiency
  • Intestinal calcium malabsorption/ steatorrhoea

Management
  • Phosphate intake should be reduced, and phosphate binders should be used to manage excess phosphate.
  • Vitamin D and calcium supplementation.
  • Parathyroidectomy should be considered if secretion remains abnormal.
  • Patients with Chronic renal failure: High Calcium, low aluminium dialysis bath.

Tertiary hyperparathyroidism (Option B)

Definition

It is a condition characterized by persistent autonomous hypercalcemic hyperparathyroidism after a kidney transplant.

Causes

Impaired graft function, non-suppressible PTH, slow gland involution, insufficient calcitriol conversion.

Diagnosis

Elevated serum calcium, elevated PTH, reduced phosphate (at least 1 year post-transplant).

Management

Surgical intervention: Mainstay of treatment: Subtotal or total parathyroidectomy with autotransplantation of parathyroid gland.

In 85% a solitary parathyroid adenoma is present
